headline.main: The Bottom Line Is the Health of All Americans

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Proponents of abandoning universal health insurance coverage for something significantly less argue, in effect, that universal coverage, and the means to achieve it, would be just too costly. But what costs are they conspicuously not counting?
docs.snippet: To the Editor:   Proponents of abandoning universal health insurance coverage for something significantly less argue, in effect, that universal coverage, and the means to achieve it, would be just too costly. But what costs are they conspicuously not...

headline.main: Out of the Attic and Asylums And Into the Camera's Eye

docs.lead_paragraph: IN THE OPENING SCENE OF "Forrest Gump," Tom Hanks, playing the title character, sits squarely on a park bench in a starched cream suit, his shirt buttoned to the collar, holding a box of chocolates. He turns to a stranger and offers her a piece of chocolate, and a taste of his life. Forrest speaks in the vowel-laden chords of the South, but the sound of his voice, like the cadence of his speech, is a note off. Soon Forrest tells us what we already suspect. With an I.Q. of 75, he has spent a lifetime being labeled dumber than most anybody. But do not expect to pity Forrest; rather, audiences may leave the theater pitying themselves. During the course of the film, which opens on Wednesday, Forrest becomes an all-American football player, a Vietnam War hero and an international Ping-Pong champ. With each accomplishment, Forrest is ushered into the White House to shake the hands of Presidents Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon; through the use of digital effects, Forrest appears in actual film clips.
